review.title: Enriching Complex Networks with Word Embeddings for Detecting Mild Cognitive Impairment from Speech Transcripts
review.abstract: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) is a mental disorder difficult to diagnose. Linguistic features, mainly from parsers, have been used to detect MCI, but this is not suitable for large-scale assessments. MCI disfluencies produce non-grammatical speech that requires manual or high precision automatic correction of transcripts. In this paper, we modeled transcripts into complex networks and enriched them with word embedding (CNE) to better represent short texts produced in neuropsychological assessments. The network measurements were applied with well-known classifiers to automatically identify MCI in transcripts, in a binary classification task. A comparison was made with the performance of traditional approaches using Bag of Words (BoW) and linguistic features for three datasets: DementiaBank in English, and Cinderella and Arizona-Battery in Portuguese. Overall, CNE provided higher accuracy than using only complex networks, while Support Vector Machine was superior to other classifiers. CNE provided the highest accuracies for DementiaBank and Cinderella, but BoW was more efficient for the Arizona-Battery dataset probably owing to its short narratives. The approach using linguistic features yielded higher accuracy if the transcriptions of the Cinderella dataset were manually revised. Taken together, the results indicate that complex networks enriched with embedding is promising for detecting MCI in large-scale assessments

MCI errors produce non-grammatical language that requires manual or high-precision automatic correction of transcripts. In this work, we modeled transcripts into complex networks and enriched them with Word Embedding (CNE) to better represent short texts generated in neuropsychological assessments. Network measurements were applied using known classifiers to automatically identify MCI in transcripts, in a binary classification task. A comparison was made with the performance of traditional approaches using Bag of Words (BoW) and linguistic features for three datasets: DementiaBank in English and Cinderella and Arizona Battery in Portuguese. Overall, CNE yielded higher accuracy than only the use of complex networks, while Demector support provided better CI scores for higher accuracy analyzers during the Cinderella Bank and Arizona Battery.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The impairment that affects memory is referred to as amnestic MCI and is therefore the most common method with the highest rate of ADHD adoption, at 15% per year compared to 1-2% for the general population. Since dementia is chronic and progressive, early diagnosis ensures a greater chance of success for patients in non-pharmacological treatment strategies such as cognitive training, physical activity and socialization. (Teixeira et al., 2012). Language is one of the most efficient sources of information for assessing cognitive function. Changes in language use are common in patients with dementia and are usually first detected by patients themselves or their family members. Therefore, the automatic analysis of discourse production is promising in diagnosing MCI in the early stages that can address potentially reversible factors.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Detection of memory impairment is based on linguistic, acoustic and demographic characteristics determined by memory analysis (in addition to dozens of neuropsychological tests. Linguistic and acoustic characteristics were used to automatically detect aphasia (Fraser et al., 2014); and AD (Fraser et al., 2015), in which speech samples were taken from the picnic image of the Western Aphasia battery (Kertesz, 1982). Other studies differentiated between different types of dementia (Garrard et al., 2014; Jarrold et al., 2014), in which speech samples were taken from the picnic image of the Western Aphasia battery (Kertesz, 1982). Davy et al al al al al al al al al al al al. (2016) also used the picnic scene to detect MCI, where subjects were asked to (manually) provide a detailed description of the scenarios for the automatic detection of MCI in speech writing.

sections.heading: 4.1 Datasets
sections.text: The data sets 2 used in our study consisted of: (i) manually segmented and transcribed samples from the history of DementiaBank and Cinderella and (ii) transcribed samples from the Arizona Battery for Communication Disorders of Dementia (ABCD), which are automatically segmented into sentences as we work on a fully automated system for detecting MCI in transcripts and evaluate a data set that has been processed automatically. DementiaBank's data set consists of short English descriptions, while the Cinderella data set contains longer Brazilian Portuguese narratives. The ABCD data set consists of very short narratives, also in Portuguese. Below, we will provide 2All data sets in the same representations used in this work, upon request to the authors, detailing the data sets, participants and the task in which they were used.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 The Cookie Theft Picture Description Dataset
sections.text: The clinical data set used for the English language was compiled during a longitudinal study conducted by the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine on Alzheimer's and related dementia and funded by the National Institute of Aging. To be eligible for enrollment in the study, all participants had to be at least 44 years old, have at least 7 years of education, have no history of nervous system disorders and do not take any neuroleptic drugs, have an initial Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) of 10 or more and be able to give informed consent. The data set includes transcripts of oral interviews with AD and related dementia patients, including those with MCI (for more details see (Becker et al., 1994). We used 43 transcriptions with MCI in addition to an additional 43 transcriptions sampled from 242 healthy older people to be used as a control group. Table 1 shows the demographic information for the two diagnostic groups.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 The Cinderella Narrative Dataset
sections.text: The dataset examined in this study included 20 subjects with MCI and 20 normal older controls diagnosed at the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Sa o Paulo (FMUSP). Table 2 shows the demographic information of the two diagnostic groups, also in Alui ́ sio et al. (2016).The criteria used to diagnose MCI came from Petersen (2004).The diagnostics were carried out by a multidisciplinary team consisting of psychiatrists, geriatricians, neurologists, neuropsychologists, speech pathologists and occupational therapists according to a criterion of consensus. Inclusion criteria for the control group were elderlies without cognitive deficits and maintaining functional capacities in daily life. The exclusion criteria for the normal group were: poorly controlled clinical diseases, sensitive deficits that were not compensated and impaired with performance in tests.

MCI subjects produced 46 narratives, while the control group produced 39. To conduct experiments with a balanced corpus, we excluded seven transcriptions from the MCI group, as was the case with the two previous data sets. We used the automatic sentence segmentation method known as DeepBond (Treviso et al., 2017) in the transcripts. Table 3 shows the demographic information. The control group had an average of 5.23 sentences per narrative, with 11 words per sentence used on average, and the MCI group had an average of 4.95 words per sentence and an average of 4.95 phrases per sentence, followed by a repeat of two sets of narratives on an average of three sentences.

sections.heading: 4.2 Features
sections.text: To classify the transcribed texts, characteristics of three different types were used: topological metrics of coexistence networks, linguistic characteristics and word diversity.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Linguistic Features
sections.text: Linguistic characteristics to classify neuropsychological assessments have been used in several studies (Roark et al., 2011; Jarrold et al., 2014; Fraser et al., 2014; Orimaye et al., 2014; Fraser et al., 2015; Vincze et al., 2016; Davy et al., 2016). We used the tool Coh-Metrix4 (Graesser et al., 2004) to extract characteristics from English transcripts, resulting in 106 characteristics. Metrics are divided into eleven categories: Descriptive, Text Easability Principal Component, Referential Cohesion, Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA), Lexical Diversity, Connective, Situation Model, Syntactic Complexity, Syntactic Pattern Density, and Readability (Flesch Reading Ease, Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level, Coh-Metrix L2 Readability).

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Bag of Words
sections.text: The representation of collections of text under the BoW assumption (i.e. without word order information) was a robust solution for text classification. In this method, transcripts are represented by a table in which the columns represent the terms (or existing words) in the transcripts and the values represent the frequency of a term in a document.

sections.heading: 4.3 Classification Algorithms
sections.text: We4cohmetrix.com 5http: / / 143.107.183.175: 22380 used four machine learning algorithms to induce classifiers from a training set: Gaussian Naive Bayes (GNB), k-Nearest Neighbor (k-NN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear and Radial Base Functions (RBF), and Random Forest (RF). We also combined these classifiers through ensemble and multi-view learning. In ensemble learning, multiple models / classifiers are generated and combined with a majority match or average of class probabilities to produce a single result (Zhou, 2012). In multiview learning, multiple classifiers are trained in different feature spaces and thus combined to produce a single result. This approach is an elegant solution compared to the combination of spatial truths to improve these features for first weighting or second weighting.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: All experiments were carried out using Scikitlearn6 (Pedregosa et al., 2011), where classifiers were not evaluated on the basis of classification accuracy, i.e. the total proportion of narratives correctly classified, and the evaluation was carried out with 5-fold cross-validations, which were however optimized with the best values, which are 0.7 in the well accepted 10-fold cross-validations, since the data sets in our study were small and the test set would have shrunk, which would have resulted in less precise measurements of accuracy. However, the threshold was optimized with the best values, which are 0.7 in the cookie theft data and 0.4 in the data sets of Cinderella and ABCD. sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this study, we used metrics of the topological characteristics of CN in a machine learning approach to distinguish between healthy patients and patients with MCI. To our knowledge, these metrics were never used to recognize MCI in language transcripts; CN were enriched with word embedding to better represent short texts produced in neuropsychological assessments; the topological characteristics of CN exceed traditional linguistic metrics in the results of individual classifiers; linguistic characteristics depend on grammatical texts to present good results, as can be seen in the results of the manually processed Cinderella dataset (Table 7); and we found that the combination of machine and multivisionary learning can improve accuracy; the accuracies found here are comparable to those of other authors, ranging from 60% to 85%, in order to determine the relevant results.
